caption: Figure 1: Pipeline. First, we train a UDF prediction network Uə on a synthetic dataset, which contains a series of local point cloud patches that are independent of specific shapes. Given a global point cloud P, we then extract a local patch P assigned to each query point q within a specified radius, and obtain the corresponding UDF values Uô (P, q). Finally, we extract the mesh corresponding to the input point cloud by incorporating the DCUDF[32] framework.
description: The figure illustrates the overall pipeline of the proposed Losf-UDF method.  It starts by training a UDF prediction network on a synthetic dataset of local point cloud patches.  Then, given a global point cloud, the method extracts a local patch around each query point and predicts the unsigned distance field (UDF) value.  Finally, mesh extraction is performed using the DCUDF framework.

caption: Figure 2: Local geometries. (a) For points on a geometry that are differentiable, the local shape at these points can be approximated by quadratic surfaces. (b) For points that are non-differentiable, we can also construct locally approximated surfaces using functions.
description: This figure shows how the local geometry of a 3D surface can be approximated by different mathematical functions, depending on the differentiability of the points on the surface.  (a) shows that for smooth, differentiable surfaces, the local geometry can be well approximated using quadratic functions (planar, parabolic, elliptic, hyperbolic). (b) illustrates that for points on non-differentiable surfaces (such as creases, corners, cusps and V-saddles), other functions are required to approximate the local geometry. This distinction is crucial for the method described in the paper for generating a synthetic dataset for training.

caption: Figure 3: Synthetic dataset for training. By manipulating functional parameters, we can readily create various smooth and sharp surfaces, subsequently acquiring pairs of point cloud patches and query points via sampling.
description: This figure shows examples of the synthetic dataset used to train the LoSF-UDF model.  The dataset consists of point cloud patches generated using mathematical functions that represent a range of smooth and sharp surface features (planar, parabolic, hyperbolic, ellipsoidal, creases, cusps, corners, v-saddles). Each patch is accompanied by query points, and their corresponding unsigned distance field (UDF) values are calculated.  By varying parameters in the generating functions, a diverse range of surface types is obtained for training, making the network robust to different shape characteristics.

caption: Figure 4: Network architecture of LoSF-UDF.
description: The figure illustrates the network architecture of LoSF-UDF, a novel neural framework for reconstructing surfaces from 3D point clouds. The network consists of two PointNets that process the local point cloud patch (P) and vectors pointing from the patch points to the query point (V). A cross-attention module combines features from these two PointNets to capture local geometric information. A series of fully connected layers then predict the unsigned distance field (UDF) value at the query point. A denoising module refines the distance estimations by adding displacements (Δd).

description: This figure compares the performance of different methods (CAP-UDF, LevelSetUDF, GeoUDF, DUDF, and the proposed LoSF-UDF) on synthetic datasets. caption: Figure 6: Reconstructed surfaces from real-world scanned point clouds.
description: This figure shows the 3D reconstruction results obtained using the proposed Losf-UDF method on real-world scanned point clouds. The results demonstrate the method's capability to reconstruct complex geometries from real-world data, showcasing its applicability in practical settings.

caption: Figure 7: Comparison of different radii for extracting patches from the point cloud on reconstruction results.
description: This figure shows the effect of different patch radii on the 3D surface reconstruction results.  The ground truth (GT) is shown alongside reconstructions using radii of 0.08, 0.10, 0.20, and 0.30.  Smaller radii may lead to incomplete reconstructions, while larger radii can smooth out details and lead to less accurate results. The optimal radius for balancing detail preservation and reconstruction accuracy needs to be determined experimentally.

caption: Figure 9: Our model demonstrates robustness to more outliers.
description: This figure shows the robustness of the proposed method to outliers in point cloud data.  The leftmost image shows the ground truth model. Subsequent images show reconstructions from point clouds with increasing percentages of outliers (10%, 25%, 50%), and finally a point cloud with both 10% outliers and 10% noise.  The results demonstrate the method's ability to produce high-quality surface reconstructions even with significant levels of noise and outliers present in the input data.
